function $f$ on $M$ and some constant vector $C.$ If the vector $C$\ in (1)
is zero, a submanifold with pointwise 1-type Gauss map is said to be of the

A lot of papers were recently published about rotational surfaces with

Euclidean space in \cite{aksoyak 1},\cite{arslan 1},\cite{arslan 2}, \cite

pointwise 1-type Gauss map were studied in \cite{bektas 1, bektas 2}.

(rotational surfaces of hyperbolic type) with pointwise 1-type Gauss map in
Minkowski space $\mathbb{E}_{1}^{4}$. They gave a characterization for flat
boost invariant surfaces with pointwise 1-type Gauss map. Also they obtain
some results for boost invariant marginally trapped surfaces with pointwise
1-type Gauss map. Ganchev and Milousheva in \cite{milo} studied three types
of rotational surfaces with two dimensional axis rotational surfaces of
elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic type in pseudo Euclidean space $\mathbb{E}
_{2}^{4}$. They classify all rotational marginally trapped surfaces of
elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic type, respectively.

In this paper, we study rotational surfaces of elliptic, hyperbolic and
parabolic type with pointwise 1-type Gauss map in four dimensional pseudo
Euclidean space and give all classifications of flat rotational surfaces of
elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic type with pointwise 1-type Gauss map. We
conclude that flat rotational surfaces of parabolic type with pointwise
1-type Gauss map has harmonic Gauss map and morever these surfaces has
parallel mean curvature vector.

where the surface $M_{1}$ is obtained by the rotation of the curve $\alpha
(s)=(x_{1}(s),x_{2}(s),x_{3}(s),0)$ about the two dimensional Euclidean
plane span$\left \{ \epsilon _{1},\epsilon _{2}\right \} .$ Without loss of
generality, we assume that the profile curve of $M_{1}$ is unit speed
spacelike curve, that is, $\left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}+\left(
x_{2}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}-\left( x_{3}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}=1$
and $x_{3}(s)>0.$ For the surface $M_{1},$\ we choose a moving frame field $
e_{1},e_{2},e_{3},e_{4}$ such that $e_{1},e_{2}$ are tangent to $M$ and $
e_{3},e_{4}$ are normal to $M$ which are given by
\begin{eqnarray*}
e_{1} &=&\left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s),x_{2}{}^{\prime }(s),x_{3}{}^{\prime
}(s)\cos t,x_{3}{}^{\prime }(s)\sin t\right) , \\
e_{2} &=&\left( 0,0,-\sin t,\cos t\right) , \\
e_{3} &=&\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\left( x_{3}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2}}}\left(
-x_{2}{}^{\prime }(s),x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s),0,0\right) , \\
e_{4} &=&\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\left( x_{3}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2}}}\left(
x_{3}{}^{\prime }(s)x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s),x_{3}{}^{\prime }(s)x_{2}{}^{\prime
}(s),(1+\left( x_{3}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2})\cos t,(1+\left(
x_{3}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2})\sin t\right) .
\end{eqnarray*}
Then it is easily seen that

\begin{theorem}
\label{teo 2}Let $M_{1}$ be the flat rotation surface of elliptic type given
by the parameterization (5). Then $M_{1}$ has pointwise 1-type Gauss map if
and only if the profile curve of $M_{1}$ is characterized in one of the
following way:

i)
\begin{eqnarray}
x_{1}(s) &=&-\frac{1}{\delta _{1}}\sin \left( -\delta _{1}s+\delta
_{2}\right) +\delta _{4}, \\
x_{2}(s) &=&\frac{1}{\delta _{1}}\cos \left( -\delta _{1}s+\delta
_{2}\right) +\delta _{4},  \notag \\
x_{3}(s) &=&\delta _{3}  \notag
\end{eqnarray}

where $\delta _{1},$\ $\delta _{2},$\ $\delta _{3}$\ and $\delta _{4}$ are
real constants and the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for the
function $f=\delta _{1}^{2}-\frac{1}{\delta _{3}^{2}}$ and $C=0.$

ii)
\begin{eqnarray}
x_{1}(s) &=&\int \left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\cos \left( -
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds,  \notag \\
x_{2}(s) &=&\int \left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\sin \left( -
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds,  \notag \\
x_{3}(s) &=&\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2},
\end{eqnarray}
where $\lambda _{1},$ $\lambda _{2},$ $\lambda _{3}$ and $\lambda _{4}$ are
real constants and the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for the
function $f(s)=\frac{1}{\left( \lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2}\right) ^{2}}\left( 
\frac{\lambda _{3}^{2}}{1+\lambda _{1}^{2}}-1\right) $ and the constant
vector\newline
$C=\lambda _{1}^{2}e_{1}\wedge e_{2}+\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda
_{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}e_{2}\wedge e_{3}.$
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We assume that $M_{1}$ has pointwise 1-type Gauss map. In that case its
Gauss map satisfies (1). By using (1) and (14), we get 
\begin{eqnarray}
-f+f\left \langle C,e_{1}\wedge e_{2}\right \rangle  &=&-A(s), \\
f\left \langle C,e_{2}\wedge e_{3}\right \rangle  &=&-B(s),  \notag \\
f\left \langle C,e_{2}\wedge e_{4}\right \rangle  &=&D(s)  \notag
\end{eqnarray}
and

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="d(s)d^{\prime}\left(s\right)-b(s)b^{\prime}\left(s\right)-c(s)c^{\prime}\left(%
s\right)=(b(s)c(s))^{\prime}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>d</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

give a relationship for non-minimal these surfaces with parallel mean
curvature vector and pointwise 1-type Gauss map of the first kind. The
proofs of theorems in this subsection are similar the proofs of theorems in
previous section, we give the theorems without proof.

where the surface $M_{2}$ is obtained by the rotation of the curve $\alpha
(s)=(x_{1}(s),x_{2}(s),0,x_{4}(s))$ about the two dimensional Euclidean
plane span$\left \{ \epsilon _{2},\epsilon _{4}\right \} .$ Without loss of
generality, we assume that the profile curve of $M_{2}$ is unit speed
spacelike curve, that is, $\left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}+\left(
x_{2}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}-\left( x_{4}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ^{2}=1$
and $x_{1}(s)>0.$ For the surface $M_{2},$\ we choose a moving frame field $
e_{1},e_{2},e_{3},e_{4}$ such that $e_{1},e_{2}$ are tangent to $M_{2}$ and $
e_{3},e_{4}$ are normal to $M_{2}$ which are given by
\begin{eqnarray*}
e_{1} &=&\left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s)\cosh t,x_{2}{}^{\prime
}(s),x_{1}{}^{\prime }(s)\sinh t,x_{4}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) , \\
e_{2} &=&\left( \sinh t,0,\cosh t,0\right) , \\
e_{3} &=&\frac{1}{\sqrt{\varepsilon \left( \left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }\right)
^{2}-1\right) }}\left( 0,x_{4}{}^{\prime }(s),0,x_{2}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ,
\\
e_{4} &=&\frac{1}{\sqrt{\varepsilon \left( \left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }\right)

x_{1}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2}\right) \sinh t,-x_{1}{}^{\prime
}(s)x_{4}{}^{\prime }(s)\right) ,
\end{eqnarray*}

^{2}-1.$ If $\left( x_{1}{}^{\prime }\right) ^{2}-1$ is positive (resp.
negative) then $\varepsilon =1$ (resp. $\varepsilon =-1$). It is easily seen

h_{11}^{3} &=&d(s),\ h_{12}^{3}=0,\ h_{22}^{3}=0, \\
h_{11}^{4} &=&c(s),\text{ \ }h_{12}^{4}=0,\text{ \ }h_{22}^{4}=-\varepsilon
b(s)  \notag
\end{eqnarray}
and
\begin{eqnarray*}
\omega _{12} &=&a(s)b(s)\omega _{2},\text{ \  \ }\omega _{13}=d(s)\omega _{1},
\text{ \  \ }\omega _{14}=c(s)\omega _{1}, \\
\omega _{23} &=&0,\text{ \  \ }\omega _{24}=\varepsilon b(s)\omega _{2},\text{
\  \ }\omega _{34}=a(s)d(s)\omega _{1}.
\end{eqnarray*}
By covariant differentiation with respect to $e_{1}$ and $e_{2}$ a
straightforward calculation gives: 
\begin{eqnarray}
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{1}}e_{1} &=&\varepsilon d(s)e_{3}-\varepsilon c(s)e_{4} \\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{2}}e_{1} &=&a(s)b(s)e_{2}  \notag \\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{1}}e_{2} &=&0  \notag \\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{2}}e_{2} &=&a(s)b(s)e_{1}+b(s)e_{4}  \notag \\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{1}}e_{3} &=&-d(s)e_{1}-\varepsilon a(s)d(s)e_{4}  \notag
\\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{2}}e_{3} &=&0  \notag \\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{1}}e_{4} &=&-c(s)e_{1}-\varepsilon a(s)d(s)e_{3}  \notag
\\
\tilde{\nabla}_{e_{2}}e_{4} &=&-\varepsilon b(s)e_{2}  \notag
\end{eqnarray}

parameterization (37). If the Gauss map of $M_{2}$\ is harmonic then it has
constant Gaussian curvatrure.
\end{theorem}

\begin{theorem}
\label{teo 5}Let $M_{2}$ be flat rotation surface of hyperbolic type given
by the parameterization (37). Then $M_{2}$ has pointwise 1-type Gauss map if
and only if the profile curve of $M_{2}$ is characterized in one of the
following way:

i)
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{1}(s) &=&\delta _{1}, \\
x_{2}(s) &=&-\frac{1}{\delta _{2}}\sinh \left( -\delta _{2}s+\delta
_{3}\right) +\delta _{4}, \\
x_{4}(s) &=&-\frac{1}{\delta _{2}}\cosh \left( -\delta _{2}s+\delta
_{3}\right) +\delta _{4},
\end{eqnarray*}

where $\delta _{1},$\ $\delta _{2},$\ $\delta _{3}$\ and $\delta _{4}$ are
real constants and the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for the
function $f=\frac{1}{\delta _{1}^{2}}-\delta _{2}^{2}$ and $C=0.$

ii)
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{1}(s) &=&\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2}, \\
x_{2}(s) &=&\int \left( \lambda _{1}^{2}-1\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\sinh \left( 
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( \lambda _{1}^{2}-1\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds, \\
x_{4}(s) &=&\int \left( \lambda _{1}^{2}-1\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\cosh \left( 
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( \lambda _{1}^{2}-1\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds,
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\lambda _{1},$ $\lambda _{2},$ $\lambda _{3}$ and $\lambda _{4}$ are
real constants and without loss of generality we assume that $\lambda
_{1}^{2}-1>0.$ Morever the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for
the function $f(s)=\frac{1}{\left( \lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2}\right) ^{2}}
\left( 1-\frac{\lambda _{3}^{2}}{\lambda _{1}^{2}-1}\right) $ and the
constant vector $C=-\lambda _{1}^{2}e_{1}\wedge e_{2}+\lambda _{1}\left(
\lambda _{1}^{2}-1\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}e_{2}\wedge e_{4}.$
\end{theorem}

\begin{theorem}
\label{teo 6} A non- minimal rotational surfaces of hyperbolic type $M_{2}$
defined by (37) has pointwise 1-type Gauss map of the first kind if and only
if $M_{2}$ has parallel mean curvature vector
\end{theorem}

\begin{corollary}
\label{cor 2}If rotational surfaces of hyperbolic type $M_{2}$ given by (37)
is minimal then it has pointwise 1-type Gauss map of the first kind.
\end{corollary}

\begin{theorem}
\label{teo 2}Let $M_{1}$ be the flat rotation surface of elliptic type given
by the parameterization (5). Then $M_{1}$ has pointwise 1-type Gauss map if
and only if the profile curve of $M_{1}$ is characterized in one of the
following way:

i)
\begin{eqnarray}
x_{1}(s) &=&-\frac{1}{\delta _{1}}\sin \left( -\delta _{1}s+\delta
_{2}\right) +\delta _{4}, \\
x_{2}(s) &=&\frac{1}{\delta _{1}}\cos \left( -\delta _{1}s+\delta
_{2}\right) +\delta _{4},  \notag \\
x_{3}(s) &=&\delta _{3}  \notag
\end{eqnarray}

where $\delta _{1},$\ $\delta _{2},$\ $\delta _{3}$\ and $\delta _{4}$ are
real constants and the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for the
function $f=\delta _{1}^{2}-\frac{1}{\delta _{3}^{2}}$ and $C=0.$

ii)
\begin{eqnarray}
x_{1}(s) &=&\int \left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\cos \left( -
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds,  \notag \\
x_{2}(s) &=&\int \left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\sin \left( -
\frac{\lambda _{3}}{\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda _{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2
}}}\ln (\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2})+\lambda _{4}\right) ds,  \notag \\
x_{3}(s) &=&\lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2},
\end{eqnarray}
where $\lambda _{1},$ $\lambda _{2},$ $\lambda _{3}$ and $\lambda _{4}$ are
real constants and the Gauss map $G=e_{1}\wedge e_{2}$ satisfies (1) for the
function $f(s)=\frac{1}{\left( \lambda _{1}s+\lambda _{2}\right) ^{2}}\left( 
\frac{\lambda _{3}^{2}}{1+\lambda _{1}^{2}}-1\right) $ and the constant
vector\newline
$C=\lambda _{1}^{2}e_{1}\wedge e_{2}+\lambda _{1}\left( 1+\lambda
_{1}^{2}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}e_{2}\wedge e_{3}.$
\end{theorem}

\end{eqnarray}
and
